required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Early Protein Supplementation in Extremely Preterm Infants Fed Human Milk
clinical_study.official_title: Early Life Protein-enriched Human Milk Diets to Increase Lean Body Mass Accretion and Diversity of the Gut Microbiome in Extremely Preterm Infants: a Randomized Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The central hypothesis of this clinical trial is that, in extremely preterm infants, protein-enriched human milk diets compared to usual human milk diets during the first 2 weeks after birth increase fat-free mass (FFM)-for-age Z scores and promote maturation of the gut microbiome at term corrected age.

detailed_description.textblock: Masked randomized clinical trial in which extremely preterm infants fed human milk will be randomly assigned to receive either a protein-enriched diet (intervention group) or a usual diet (control group) within the first 96 hours after birth.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)
study_design_info.masking_description: Caregivers and primary outcome evaluators will be masked. Nutrition room staff not involved in patient care will be responsible for determining participant allocation to one of the supplementation groups by opening sequentially numbered sealed envelopes, dispensing feeding syringes with the allocated human milk diet (protein-enriched or usual), and masking caregivers administering the assigned dietary intervention.

primary_outcome.description: FFM accretion will be estimated by air displacement plethysmography

secondary_outcome.description: FM accretion will be estimated by air displacement plethysmography
Percent BF will be estimated by air displacement plethysmography

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Birth to 36 weeks postmenstrual age or hospital discharge
secondary_outcome.description: Weight, length, and head circumference measurements at regular intervals

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Birth to 36 weeks postmenstrual age or hospital discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with postnatal growth failure
Number of participants with diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Birth to 120 days or discharge, whichever occurs first
secondary_outcome.description: Diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis stage 2 or 3

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with diagnosis of intestinal perforation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Birth to 120 days or discharge, whichever occurs first

secondary_outcome.description: Death prior to 121 days of birth
Diagnosis of sepsis with positive blood cultures

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of days alive and receiving full enteral feeding
secondary_outcome.description: Total number of full enteral feeding days

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of episodes of feeding intolerance
secondary_outcome.description: Interruption or cessation of enteral feeds for a period greater than 12 hours for abnormal abdominal examination

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of hospital stay in days
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Birth to 120 days or discharge, whichever occurs first
secondary_outcome.description: From day of admission to day of hospital discharge to home

other_outcome.description: Determined by molecular analyses of fecal samples

arm_group.description: Infants in this group will receive protein-enriched expressed human milk or donor human milk during the first 2 weeks after birth.
Infants in this group will receive either expressed human milk or donor human milk during the first 2 weeks after birth.

intervention.description: 1.2 g of human-based protein will be added to each 100 ml of human milk administered
Human-based protein will not be added to the human milk administered.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Gestational age â‰¤ 28 weeks of gestation
- Postnatal age < 96 hours
Exclusion Criteria:
- Congenital malformations
- Chromosomal anomalies
- Terminal illness needing to limit or withhold support
